p: So, the aims of this work are firstly to test the in vitro phytotoxic activity (of previously analysed commercial essential oils, winter savory, peppermint, and anise, in order to assure their main compounds by GC/MS) against seed germination and seedling growth of P. oleracea, a cosmopolitan annual weed of tropical and subtropical climates; L. multiflorum, because Lolium spp. has been ranked as one of the specimens most frequently exhibiting herbicide resistance in many countries [ 30, 31, 32]; and E. crus-galli, a serious weed of irrigation crops, especially rice. Secondly, we aim to corroborate in vivo the previous in vitro phytotoxic effect using a commercial emulsifiable concentrate with the more phytotoxic essential oils and finally, we will study their potential hazard against maize ( Zea mays L.), rice ( Oryza sativa L.), and tomato ( Solanum lycopersicum L.) seeds in order to obtain selective bioherbicides for food crops.
